newsitem.title: USA: U.N. panel approves Iraq February pricing formula.
newsitem.headline: U.N. panel approves Iraq February pricing formula.

text.p: The U.N. Security Council sanctions committee on Iraq Wednesday approved the February pricing formula for crude sales under the oil-for-food plan, Western diplomats said.
No member of the 15-member panel objected to the formula, which revised terms according to changing world oil prices.
"There were just some simple revisions due to the oil price," said the diplomat.
Prices were tied to three benchmark crudes: Brent for European customers, West Texas Intermediate for the U.S. and Oman/Dubai for the Far East.

On Wednesday, the U.N. said two additional Iraq contracts were approved by the four-member board of oil experts, or overseers, charged with reviewing all contracts. The total number of contracts approved since the deal was implemented on December 10 now stands at 26.
Iraq was said to be close to the $2 billion ceiling on oil sales allowed under the plan, and already cut volumes in some contracts to stay below the limit.
Iraq was granted a partial lifting of U.N. trade sanctions to sell oil for humanitarian relief for its people, suffering from a trade ban imposed in 1990 after Baghdad's troops invaded Kuwait.
More than two-thirds of oil sales receipts were earmarked for buying food, medicine and supplies, with the balance to pay for reparations and expenses.
Monies from the sales were expected to enter a special escrow account sometime in mid-January, paving the way for import purchases, diplomats said.
